title: ErdÅ‘s Problem #1119: Families of Entire Functions with Cardinal Constraints
description: If a family of entire functions has at most ğ”ª distinct values at each point, must the family have cardinality â‰¤ ğ”ª? Answer: YES if ğ”ªâº < ğ” , UNDECIDABLE if ğ”ªâº = ğ” .

overview.historicalContext: This generalizes Wetzel's 1963 problem, which ErdÅ‘s solved in 1964. The original problem asked about countable values (ğ”ª = â„µâ‚€), and ErdÅ‘s showed the answer depends on the Continuum Hypothesis. This problem extends to intermediate cardinals ğ”ª with â„µâ‚€ < ğ”ª < ğ” . Hayman (1974) noted the easy case ğ”ªâº < ğ” . Kumar-Shelah (2017) and Schilhan-Weinert (2024) showed the case ğ”ªâº = ğ”  is undecidable.
overview.problemStatement: Let ğ”ª be an infinite cardinal with â„µâ‚€ < ğ”ª < ğ”  = 2^{â„µâ‚€}. Let {f_Î±} be a family of entire functions such that, for every zâ‚€ âˆˆ â„‚, there are at most ğ”ª distinct values of f_Î±(zâ‚€). Must {f_Î±} have cardinality at most ğ”ª?
overview.proofStrategy: The answer splits into two cases based on whether ğ”ªâº < ğ”  or ğ”ªâº = ğ” . In the first case, the answer is YES (provable in ZFC). In the second case, the problem is undecidable in ZFC: Kumar-Shelah constructed a model where YES holds, while Schilhan-Weinert constructed a model where NO holds.
keyInsights: The problem generalizes Wetzel's question from â„µâ‚€ to arbitrary intermediate cardinals ğ”ª
If ğ”ªâº < ğ” , the answer is YESâ€”the family size is bounded by the local multiplicity
If ğ”ªâº = ğ”  (e.g., ğ”ª = â„µâ‚, ğ”  = â„µâ‚‚), the answer is independent of ZFC
Kumar-Shelah (2017) showed YES is consistent with ZFC in this case
Schilhan-Weinert (2024) showed NO is also consistent with ZFC
The identity theorem for entire functions is key: distinct entire functions agree on at most countably many points

sections.title: Basic Definitions
sections.summary: Defines entire functions, the set of values at a point, Wetzel families with bounded values, and the main question about family cardinality.

sections.title: The Original Wetzel Problem
sections.summary: ErdÅ‘s's 1964 solution to Wetzel's problem: countable values implies countable family iff Â¬CH. If CH holds, uncountable Wetzel families exist.

sections.title: The Easy Case
sections.summary: When ğ”ªâº < ğ” , the answer is YES. This is 'easy to see' according to Hayman (1974).

sections.title: The Undecidable Case
sections.summary: When ğ”ªâº = ğ”  (e.g., ğ”ª = â„µâ‚, ğ”  = â„µâ‚‚), the problem is undecidable. Kumar-Shelah and Schilhan-Weinert showed both YES and NO are consistent.

sections.title: The Set-Theoretic Framework
sections.summary: Cardinal arithmetic background: the continuum 2^{â„µâ‚€}, GCH implications, and existence of intermediate cardinals.

sections.title: Entire Functions Background
sections.summary: Why entire functions are special: the identity theorem says distinct entire functions agree on at most countably many points.

sections.title: Connection to Wetzel's Problem
sections.summary: Wetzel's original question and its equivalence to Â¬CH. This problem generalizes that setting.

sections.title: The General Framework
sections.summary: Formalizes the general problem: does local multiplicity bound global cardinality for families of entire functions?

sections.title: The Complete Picture
sections.summary: Complete characterization: YES if ğ”ªâº < ğ”  (provable in ZFC), undecidable if ğ”ªâº = ğ” .

sections.title: Main Problem Statement
sections.summary: Full formalization combining ErdÅ‘s's Wetzel solution, the easy case, and the undecidability result.

conclusion.summary: ErdÅ‘s Problem #1119 is SOLVED. The answer is YES if ğ”ªâº < ğ”  (provable in ZFC) and UNDECIDABLE if ğ”ªâº = ğ” . Kumar-Shelah (2017) showed YES is consistent with ZFC when ğ”  = â„µâ‚‚, while Schilhan-Weinert (2024) showed NO is also consistent.
conclusion.implications: This demonstrates a deep connection between complex analysis (entire functions) and set theory (cardinal arithmetic). The identity theorem for entire functions constrains how much distinct functions can agree, but the global implications depend on set-theoretic assumptions.
openQuestions: Are there other natural function classes where similar undecidability arises?
What is the exact set-theoretic characterization of when YES holds?
Does the problem have a definite answer under large cardinal assumptions?
